Title:
A new species of Scopulariopsis and its synergistic
pathogenicity on cotton plants infected by Verticillium dahliea
Keywords:
A new species of Scopulariopsis and its synergistic
pathogenicity on cotton plants infected by Verticillium dahliea
Abstract:
A new species, Scopulariopsis gossypii, was found to be
present in the vascular bundles of cotton plants infected by
Verticillium dahliea which is an economically important pathogen in
Hangzhou, China. The fungus was only present in the diseased plants, but
it never became isolated from the healthy plants. Scanning electron
microscopy demonstrated that the fungus was present in parenchyma cells
enclosing vessels in dark brown vascular tissues of stems, and
especially produced the asexual conidia within the tissues. Phylogenetic
analysis of combined nuclear ribosomal ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 (ITS) and D1/D2
region of the 28S rDNA as well as translation elongation factor 1-alpha
(TEF1) and beta-tubulin(TUB) gene showed S. gossypii preserved in
culture collection representing an undescribed species of
Scopulariopsis, Microascaceae. In this study, the characteristics of
sexual and asexual stages were described, illustrated and compared with
similar taxa. In addition, the molecular and morphological analyses
indicated that S. gossypii was a distinct species of Scopulariopsis.
Pathogenicity tests confirmed that S. gossypii was an opportunistic
pathogen that causes leaf interveinal chlorosis and vascular browning of
cotton plants, which was proved by dipping method to inoculate wounded
roots. However S. gossypii did not infect host with undamaged roots.
Moreover, coinoculation with S. gossypii and V. dahliea significantly
increased disease severity.
